title: Victor Halward
text:
Nelson Victor Halward (, called Victor; 12 December 189717 December 1953) was an English <a href="Anglicanism">Anglican</a> bishop in <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>. He was the <a href="Colony%20Commissioner">Colony Commissioner</a> of <a href="The%20Scout%20Association%20of%20Hong%20Kong">the Boy Scout Association, Hong Kong Branch</a> from 1934 to 1950.
Biography.
Victor Halward was educated at <a href="The%20King%27s%20School%2C%20Canterbury">The King's School, Canterbury</a>. In 1916 he went straight from school into the <a href="British%20Army">army</a>, at first in the <a href="Royal%20Artillery">Royal Artillery</a>, then in 1917 he was commissioned as <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> in the <a href="Gloucestershire%20Regiment">Gloucestershire Regiment</a>. In 1919 he was awarded the <a href="Military%20Cross">Military Cross</a>:
In June 1919 Halward was promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a>. He then left the army and went up to <a href="Jesus%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Jesus College, Cambridge</a>. After graduating he studied theology at <a href="Westcott%20House%2C%20Cambridge">Westcott House, Cambridge</a>, and was <a href="Ordination">ordained</a> in the <a href="Church%20of%20England">Church of England</a>. He was <a href="curate">curate</a> at St Saviour's Church, <a href="Croydon">Croydon</a>, 1922–25, then in 1926 he moved to <a href="Hong%20Kong">Hong Kong</a> as Diocesan Chaplain to the Anglican Church there (<a href="Chung%20Hua%20Sheng%20Kung%20Hui">Chung Hua Sheng Kung Hui</a>). He was also the Scoutmaster of <a href="St.%20Paul%27s%20College%2C%20Hong%20Kong">St Paul's College</a> in Hong Kong and was enthusiastic in <a href="Scouting">Scouting</a> activities. He was priest-in-charge in <a href="Kowloon%20Tong">Kowloon Tong</a> 1933–36. From 1936 to 1946 – throughout the <a href="Second%20Sino-Japanese%20War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a> and <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> – he was based in Canton (now <a href="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a>) in southern China as a missionary for the <a href="Church%20Missionary%20Society">Church Missionary Society</a>, but continued as Hong Kong Colony Commissioner for Boy Scouts despite the <a href="Japanese%20occupation%20of%20Hong%20Kong">Japanese occupation of Hong Kong</a>. During his commissionership, the <a href="Scout%20Movement">Scout Movement</a> rooted among the Chinese population in Hong Kong. Halward appointed Chinese district commissioners and they significantly helped to develop Scouting in Hong Kong. Through his connections in Canton he established cooperation with the <a href="Scouts%20of%20China">Scouts of China</a>. He was awarded the <a href="Silver%20Wolf%20Award%20%28The%20Scout%20Association%29">Silver Wolf</a>, the highest honour in <a href="The%20Scout%20Association">The Scout Association</a>. During the Japanese occupation Halward was interned in the <a href="concentration%20camp">concentration camp</a> in Canton.
After the war Halward was Assistant <a href="Bishop%20of%20Victoria">Bishop of Victoria</a> (Hong Kong and South China) 1946–51 (for <a href="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a>) and Assistant <a href="Bishop%20of%20British%20Columbia">Bishop of British Columbia</a> 1951–53. He was consecrated a bishop on <a href="James%20the%20Great">St James's Day</a> 1946 (25 July), by <a href="Geoffrey%20Fisher">Geoffrey Fisher</a>, <a href="Archbishop%20of%20Canterbury">Archbishop of Canterbury</a>, at <a href="St%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BPaul%27s%20Cathedral">St Paul's Cathedral</a>.
